title: ‘There's a half-life to these protests and boycotts': Will Spotify's decision to keep Joe Rogan's podcast lead to a wave of cancelations?
text:
Their actions come as Neil Young announced he would pull his music off the platform if Spotify continued to feature Rogan's podcast, “The Joe Rogan Experience.” He said Spotify is “spreading fake information about vaccines — potentially causing death to those who believe the disinformation being spread by them.”

On Wednesday, Spotify ultimately allowed Young to pull the plug but made no changes to Rogan's podcast, which was the most popular podcast worldwide on Spotify last year.

https://twitter.com/enenbee/status/1486825123403341828https://twitter.com/HoneyBeeGeek/status/1487127952827371520Will the wave of reported cancelations last? Probably not, said Mark Cohen, director of retail studies at Columbia University.

“There's a half-life to these protests and boycotts,” he told MarketWatch. “They don't last very long, and lots of folks who say they're canceling this subscription probably aren't or they'll renew them.”

Spotify didn't respond to MarketWatch's inquiry regarding how many users canceled their subscriptions this week and it didn't respond to questions about the difficulty some users reportedly encountered attempting to cancel their subscriptions.

But those who wish to teach Spotify a lesson for sticking with Rogan, an anti-vax proponent, will have a long way to go. Spotify has approximately 172 million subscribers worldwide, and has roughly a 31% share of the global music-streaming market (ahead of Apple AAPL with around 15%).

https://twitter.com/TristanSnell/status/1486888238480596993Right now, “Spotify is making a calculated decision that this will pass,” Cohen added.

“Generally speaking, that's correct. But they might be risking far more damage than they can imagine because the subject of the dispute is something that's explosive,” he said referring to health evidence on the dangers of not getting vaccinated against COVID-19.

In a tweet posted on Thursday, World Health Organization Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus thanked Young for his advocacy against spreading lies about COVID-19.

Apple Music AAPL took a dig at Spotify on Thursday, reminding customers that they “can listen to Young's entire catalog.”

https://twitter.com/DrTedros/status/1486723273362575361
